texts.shortText:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This is a large, thick, cushion-like sponge with a smooth surface that is thrown into rounded lobes. There are usually several round oscula positioned towards the tops of the lobes. Texture is firm and elastic and colour orange, internally orange-yellow.
Up to at least 300 mm across and typically about 20-50 mm thick.

Global: Widespread across the Arctic, Pacific Ocean, North Atlantic, Mediterranean, down the west coast of Africa to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia and west coast of South Africa.

A widespread and common benthic species found on hard substrata from the low water mark to depths of over 1000 m. Thought to be unpalatable to most predators and often found growing on shells occupied by hermit crabs, which may gain protection from the sponge. Has been investigated as a possible source of antibiotics, anti-fouling and other biologically active compounds.
Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.

Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
One of several Suberites species that occur in the region (see references below) but the most common of these, S. dandelenae, occurs in deeper waters of 80-500 m and is yellow rather than orange.

Samaai, T & Gibbons, MJ (2005). Demospongiae taxonomy and biodiversity of the Benguela region on the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 1, 1-96. (p. 28).

Samaai, T, Maduray, S, Janson, L, Gibbons, MJ, Ngwakum, B & Teske, PR (2017). A new species of habitatâ€“forming Suberites (Porifera, Demospongiae, Suberitida) in the Benguela upwelling region (South Africa). Zootaxa, 4254(1), 49-81.
